results.title: Life at the top
results.creator_credit: Melissa Juhanson, Film Victoria and Victoria. Ministry of Housing and Construction
results.brief_description: Radiating from a dreary housing estate come the personalities of colourful individuals that have made their own worlds in a potentially depressing situation of high rise living in Australia. A multi-award winning film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Melissa Juhanson, Film Victoria and Victoria. Ministry of Housing and Construction

results.title: Life at the top
results.creator_credit: Pierre des Bonnet, Anne Boggan and United Nations
results.brief_description: A look at life in three highly industrialised countries in Europe: France, Romania and the United Kingdom, each of which seeks to further its national development goals through population planning. Focuses on the role of individual women, as influenced by their government’s policies, in determining family size.

results.title: Life at Salt Point: salt water ecology
results.brief_description: Salt Point, California is the setting for a broad survey of three marine ecosystems; the open sea, the wave-swept, and the tidal. The open-sea ecosystem focuses on a variety of planktonic inhabitants, their adaptations to a floating environment, and the marine food chain. The coastal ecosystems (wave-swept and tidal) show organism adaptation to varying water conditions, habitats within habitats, interaction within a species and interaction between species.

results.title: Life at Little Lon
results.creator_credit: Jo Lane, Ann Darrouzet, Jo Bell, Film Victoria and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Presented by Robyn Williams, this documentary looks at Australia’s largest urban archaeological project, the excavation of an area known as Little Lon (Little Lonsdale Street). The excavations unearthed tens of thousands of artefacts and remnants of human history. The program also shows how archaeology can illuminate our understanding of places and times. Includes study notes on inside of slick.

results.title: Life along the waterways
results.creator_credit: John A. Haeseler, Roy Wilcox and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Depicts the many forms of plant and animal life found near the streams, of ponds, rivers and marshes that make up a waterway system. Illustrates the dependence of the members of this community on the waterway, and points out their activities throughout the spring, summer and autumn seasons. The film indicates the physical changes of the waterway in its growth from a brook to a river.

results.title: Life's burning desire
results.creator_credit: Stephen Cummins, Martin Guinness, Feel Good Films and Fleur Productions
results.brief_description: ‘Life burnings desire’ follows the path of dancer, choreographer and actor Paul Mercurio. Specifically, the programme focuses on Mercurio’s work with CONTACT, a new dance theatre piece conceived, choreographed and performed by Mercurio and his dance company ACE (Australian Choreographic Ensemble). His relationship with this project serves as a metaphor for his wider body of work.

results.title: Lies spies and Olympics
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Rob McAuley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The 1956 Olympic Games held in Melbourne have become etched in Australian mythology as a watershed in our sporting, cultural and civic history. This fascinating documentary examines the era in which they were held, post World War II, and how that influenced both the staging of the Games and some of the extraordinary events which occurred during it (such as the defection of Hungarian athletes). It looks beyond the myth to discover a compelling story of deceit, clashing egos and local and international politics which almost turned the so-called ‘Friendly Games’ into a national disaster.

results.title: Lies [Widescreen] (E)
results.creator_credit: Jang Sun-Woo, Chul Shin, Korea Pictures and Shincine Communications
results.brief_description: Jang Sun-Woo’s Lies (based on a notorious Korean novel, whose author Jang Jung Il was sentenced to six months jail over its content) takes the very simple premise of a sexual affair between an older man and a younger woman and turns it on its head. Right from its opening scenes where the ‘actors’ discuss their roles and the difficulties of performing on-screen sex, the audience is led into deep analysis of what film authenticity means. This becomes a tantalizing proposition as the affair between J (Lee Sang Hyun), 38-year-old married man and the innocent Y (Kim Tae Yeon), an 18-year-old student determined to lose her virginity, becomes a sadomasochistic one. As these two people explore just how far the other is willing to go, we as an audience are asking the same question of the film as each erotic act becomes seemingly more real. Sun-Woo heightens this by adopting a documentary verite style that distances itself from its main protagonists. Finally the blurred boundaries between what is performance and what isn’t ultimately begs the question, ‘does the camera lie?’. In Korean with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jang Sun-Woo, Chul Shin, Korea Pictures and Shincine Communications

results.title: Lickety-split licorice
results.creator_credit: Jan Steen, Joe Hayward, Moreland-Latchford Productions and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: A boy and girl making liquorice, stretch it outside in a tangled web which leads to utter chaos as people become entangled in it. When someone snips the gigantic piece of liquorice, the scenes flash rapidly backwards to reality. No spoken commentary - English intertitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jan Steen, Joe Hayward, Moreland-Latchford Productions and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: Licensed to drive (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Jeff regains his licence after losing it for drink-driving. He is determined to keep it this time and has to find ways of sticking to the zero limit. Eventually he is able to meet the challenge of going to a party and enjoying himself without alcohol. He can keep to his decision : “When I drink I don’t drive and when I drive I just don’t drink”.
